p: Most (>95%) cases of HAT occur in Central and West Africa, where the important vectors are subspecies of G. palpalis and G. fuscipes, which are riverine tsetse. These species have very similar physiology to the savanna species of East and Southern Africa, including G. pallidipes, and hence we would expect that populations of riverine tsetse would decline if they were exposed to the temperature increases reported in the Zambezi Valley of Zimbabwe.
